body:
To cooperate trustworthily in building an open science world is the vision and mission of the iDAI.world. It is the result of a long joint development by many partners. Its origin lies in the initiatives of the Research Archive for Ancient Sculpture in Cologne. From this tradition, two key partners of the DAI in the stricter sense of informatics, programming and infrastructure are the Cologne University’s chair for Archaeoinformatics and the Regional Computing Center in Cologne (RRZK). They were joined by many others over time, namely the Chair for Computer Graphics at the University of Applied Sciences in Dresden, and the Archaeocopter and Archaeonautic project at Dresden University and the Free University in Berlin. Numerous national and international cooperations are shaping the iDAI.world as a service for the community

Without its partners, friends and users, the offer of the iDAI.world would never have arisen in the present form.

title: Cooperation in national and international infrastructures

tiles.headline: ARIADNE
tiles.text: The goal was the integration of European archaeological repositories, which created a searchable catalog of datasets including unpublished reports, images, maps, databases and other kinds of archaeological information accessible online.

tiles.headline: Archaeocopter and Archaeonautic
tiles.text: Recording archaeology with low cost unmanned aerial vehicles.

tiles.headline: CARARE
tiles.text: CARARE aims to advance professional practice and foster appreciation of digital archaeological and architectural heritage through the promotion for public benefit of digitization, connection. enhancement, and use of digital content.

tiles.headline: CeramEgypt
tiles.text: Pottery production and consumption in Ptolemaic-Roman Egypt based on pottery finds from surveys.

tiles.headline: DARIAH-DE
tiles.text: A digital research infrastructure for humanities and cultural sciences that offers researchers a platform. Six different tasks are fulfilled by DARIAH-DE: dissemination, services, data, expertise, management and coordination with DARIAH-EU.

tiles.headline: DARIAH-EU
tiles.text: The Digital Research Infrastructure for the Arts and Humanities (DARIAH) aims to enhance and support digitally-enabled research and teaching across the arts and humanities.

tiles.headline: E-RiHS
tiles.text: The European Research Infrastructures for Heritage Sciences’ mission is to deliver integrated access to expertise, data and technologies through a standardized approach.

tiles.headline: Einstein Center: Chronoi
tiles.text: The Einstein Center Chronoi has been founded in order to investigate time and related aspects such as awareness of time, time management, time reckoning and temporality in interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary formats under the rubric of 'Chronoi'.

tiles.headline: IANUS
tiles.text: The project IANUS of the DAI aimed to develop structures for a national research data center for archaeology and classics in Germany and how to generally deal with digital data and methods.

tiles.headline: Images in Pausanias
tiles.text: The purpose of the database “Images in Pausanias” is to systematically register all figurative works of art found in Pausanias and make them accessible for combined online research.

tiles.headline: NAHAN
tiles.text: NAHAN, the North African Heritage Archives Network, is a network of institutions holding archive material on monuments in North Africa. An open-access platform is being developed, on which materials are going to be published.

tiles.headline: Open Context
tiles.text: Open Context reviews, edits, plans and prepares data, cleans and organizes it, annotates digital data with stable web identifiers for correct citation, digitally archives it and also collaborates with other publishers.

tiles.headline: OCRE
tiles.subhead: Online Coins of the Roman Empire
tiles.text: OCRE (Online Coins of the Roman Empire) is a new tool designed to help in the identification, cataloging, and research of coinage of the Roman Empire.

tiles.headline: ONLAAH
tiles.text: As a project of a consortium of several institutions, the platform ONLAAH offers online courses on African archaeology, African heritage and African heritage management.

tiles.headline: Our Place: Our Place in the World
tiles.text: The purpose of the research of Neolithic sites in southwestern Asia has been to identify innovative theoretical approaches to investigate how these first large, permanently co-resident communities functioned, and how and why they networked with each other.

tiles.headline: Pelagios
tiles.text: The Pelagios Network links information online through common references to places. The core activities of Pelagios are annotation, collaboration, gazetteers, pedagogy, registry and visualization.

tiles.headline: The Hellespont Project
tiles.text: The Hellespont Project combines the digital collections of Greek and Roman antiquities of the Perseus Digital Library and the German Archaeological Institute with text using the metadata format CIDOC.

tiles.headline: Propylaeum
tiles.text: The collaboration of the DAI and Propylaeum aims to create relationships between biblographical data and the geographical information in iDAI.gazetteer within ProplyaeumSEARCH.

tiles.headline: SSHOC
tiles.text: The Social Sciences and Humanities Open Cloud offers scalable and flexible access to research data in an open source environment, interconnects new and existing infrastructures to enforce interdisciplinary research.
